results.title: A Bug's life [DVD]
results.creator_credit: John Lasseter, Darla Anderson, Kevin Reher, Pixar Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: A Bug’s Life is a perfect example of how technology can be used to tell a good story. The computer generated animation from this Pixar film is amazing, but what makes it watchable are the gorgeous characters and enthralling story. When Flik endangers the future of the ant colony, Princess Atta sends him away to find help. A gang of grasshoppers- led by the menacing Hopper, will return by the end of the summer to accept the colony’s offering, which will take the colony the whole summer to collect. Flik runs into a group of circus performing insects who he mistakenly thinks are warriors. Will the colourful troupe and Flik be able to save the colony from Hopper’s wrath? Includes the voices of Kevin Spacey, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Phyllis Diller, Denis Leary, Madeline Kahn and Roddy McDowall. The film also includes the Pixar animated short, “The Game”, which won the 1997 Academy Award for Best Animated Short.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Lasseter, Darla Anderson, Kevin Reher, Pixar Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures

results.title: A Brilliant madness [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Mark Samels, Randall MacLowry, American Experience and Yellow Jersey Films
results.brief_description: This is an inspirational biographical documentary on the real John Nash, subject of the feature film “A Beautiful mind” which cast Russell Crowe in the role of John Nash. Born in 1928 in Bluefield, Virginia, John grew up to be an exceptionally brilliant mathematician attending Princeton University. There he was described as odd, non-conformist, elitist, brash, egocentric, genius, competitive, a man who would push the boundaries in the mathematical world with his theories. At Princeton he devised his Nobel Prize (awarded decades later in 1994) winning “Game Theory” which describes strategies in competition, particularly in the area of economics. In 1951 he joined the faculty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge where he became renowned as one of the brightest mathematicians in the world. However in 1958 at the age of 30 his life took a dramatic turn when he suffered a psychotic episode and was hospitalised. He was eventually diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia. For the next three decades John Nash’s life was turned upside down. His personality was dogged by delusions of grandeur, conspiracies and paranoia requiring several bouts of hospitalisation until the 1980s when a second transformation occurred - a re-awakening. Off medication since the 1970s it appears that John Nash almost willed the voices away, rejecting the madness that had nearly destroyed his life. Through archival footage, stills, re-enactments and interviews with family, friends, colleagues and John Nash himself, this beautifully presented documentary gives an honest and factual account of this highly respected but somewhat eccentric mathematician’s journey into the darker side of life. Narrated by Liev Schreiber.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mark Samels, Randall MacLowry, American Experience and Yellow Jersey Films

results.title: 88 down under
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Paul Humfress and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A promotional film for the Bicentenary celebrations which sets out to show the diversity of Australia, its history, wealth, cities, tourist attractions and above all its people and their achievements. Narrated in the style of the Paul Hogan tourist commercials.

results.title: 84 Charing Cross Road
results.creator_credit: David Jones, Geoffrey Helman and Brooksfilms
results.brief_description: Feisty Helen Hanff (Anne Bancroft) just loves rare books, the sort you can’t get in New York. Little does she know that a letter to a small second-hand bookshop in London will lead to a twenty year love affair with the staff and the city. Helen strikes up a particularly affectionate correspondence with Frank Doel (Anthony Hopkins) at Marks & Co. in ‘84 Charing Cross Road. Her letters are soon followed by food parcels to the food-rationed staff, and insights into life across the Atlantic. A heartwarming, charming film based upon the memoirs of Helen Hanff and the play adapted from her book.

results.title: A Boy, a dog and a frog
results.creator_credit: Gary Templeton, John Sturner and Evergreen Films
results.brief_description: This film follows the adventures of a small boy and his dog as they spend a day trying to capture a playful frog at a nearby pond. The film is a delightful, non-verbal production that will provide amusement and enjoyment for audiences of all ages.

results.title: A Boy's life
results.brief_description: Although embracing vastly different styles and aesthetices, the three films comprising “A boy’s life” present an intriguingly lucid biography of developing sexuality - from childhood via puberty to college days. Using humour to explore painful issues of emerging identity, both ‘Dottie Gets Spanked’ (director, Todd Haynes) and ‘Trevor’ (director, Peggy Rajski) are remarkable in that they address one of the ultimate taboos by acknowledging that children can and do have an awareness of their own sexuality. The third short film, ‘A Friend of Dorothy’ this is the tale of a sexually confused young man in his first term at college. Each film rings with authenticity: they represent stories, experiences and emotions that many gay men will instantly recognise.

results.title: A Book for every child
results.creator_credit: Alastair Matheson, John Balcomb, Mallica Vanarathon and UNICEF
results.brief_description: Enormous book shortages plague nearly every emerging nation. The creative potential of teachers is being tapped in India, Thailand and Uganda, where they are writing, illustrating and even hand-producing books for their own class rooms. From them, children are also learning to make this most basic teaching tool. Narrated by Edward Kemp.

results.title: A Blow, a kiss
results.creator_credit: Rey Carlson, Helene Nicol, Rhonda Schepisi and Great Southern Films
results.brief_description: A 10 year old boy and his father help an injured man who has crashed his motorcycle. The boy is confused and deeply affected by the reactions of both his father and the father of the motorcyclist, in the face of this trauma. Based on a short story by Tim Winton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rey Carlson, Helene Nicol, Rhonda Schepisi and Great Southern Films
